title: VR Headset for 5.5" Phone Screens (iPhone 6+ and Oneplus One Verified)

description.text:
Update: I used the Cardboard tuner: https://www.google.com/get/cardboard/viewerprofilegenerator/
to create a profile for my particular setup. So if you're using amazon's "Ajax Scientific Polished Glass Double Lenses Spherical (Bi-convex), 38mm Diameter, 50mm Focal Length", and have an IPD of 65mm, the attached QR code should work for you too. A VR viewer that will fit 5.5" phone screens. Supplement this part with lens holders here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:634507 ...and phone clips here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:634492
(Note that these aren't absolutely necessary. Rubber bands will attach any size or shape of phone to this headset nicely.) Also recommended:
3 X 0.5" neodymium magnets. 2 on the outside, one on the inside.
1.5" elastic for headband.
Foam Padding for head comfort. Summary:
I modified my previous viewer: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:634518
to have button access on the outside of the viewer instead of the inside. In so doing, I also had to narrow the screen window slightly, so the fit for the Note4 is now a little less than ideal. I also added an additional phone clip nubbin to the top of the headset, so the upper clip should now snap into place just like the bottom one.

title: Acoustic Horn for iPhone4 with Otterbox "Defender" Case

description.text: This is an acoustic amplifying horn for an iPhone4 or 4s Phone in an Otterbox "Defender" series case. It helps direct the sound (thus amplifying) and increases the lower frequency response of the phone's speakers slightly. Don't expect it to sound like a Bose system but it works great in the pocket of my coat while walking.

I used a support that was 17.5mm high to support the inside of the base. The rest of the horn was unsupported and printe ok as there were no sharp overhangs.
This is a work in progress but is useful.

title: Table saw for Dremel 4000 (with drill bracket Fixed)

description.text:
Perfect for a straight cut with the materials such as wood, steel, epoxy or small screws.
Use the table extension for larger piece or for more stability and control, but also protects spark when cutting steel.
INFO: To adapt other drill you can try with "All Motor Bracket.STL" NEW (February 2017) :
  • Infill : 60% (minimum)

  • Added a new version of the table saw with adjustable guides is rotating angle protractor (by 25° increments), as well as a new dremel support.

  • Added a support for other motor (All_motor_bracket.STL), without the threading but with Velcro passes 15mm width as here:

This is a 2x2 doorway tile meant to be compatible with OpenForge. There are a few door styles available to download in other files, so I won't include them here.  
Insert a pin through the hole, and through the door you choose to print out and it will act as a hinge.

author: UrbanAtWork

description.text:
OK, I almost feel silly posting this, but.., I really did break one of the carbon fiber arms, and I really did print a replacement that I designed. The design was an arduous, 2 mins in solidworks with a patience testing 4 mins on the printer. Pros:
  • It dimensionally fits
  • It's rugged enough to hold up basic crashes
  • it only takes 4 mins to make (and another 2 mins to design if you want to do it yourself)
    • Cons:
  • With PLA, its a LOT heavier than the stock items, you will need ballast to offset. I used zip ties on the far side of the opposing rail.
  • it also has more flex, which may be what is makinit unstable to throttle adjustments
    • If you need a quick replacement, this will work, at least until amazon can send you a replacement parts kit. Peace out.

title: mount for low-cost 2m ground plane antenna

description.text:
My first goal was that it stores easily in a closet or in the back window of a pickup, then I wanted to make it as cheaply as possible out of stuff I had lying around.  
All you need is a SO-239, cable, some wire, and a bit of 1"/25mm PVC and this mount.  I might post some revisions, but this one tests out at barely above 1.0 SWR on both my Yaesu 897d display and my Elecraft W2 tester.

See the photos for how to assemble.  This fits 1"/25mm o.d. PVC pipe.  If you have a different diameter of PVC, just resize the lower half of the mount.  
Tension from the cable running inside the PVC tube (or other mount) helps keep the ground plane wires at a roughly 45 degree angle.  
After you've picked your center frequency, cut the wires down to 1-2 CM above your desired length, then slowly trim them while checking your SWM.  I got mine under 1:1.1 in a few minutes.  
I used 1/16 stainless welding rod -- it's just strong enough to keep a bend and stay straight while not being too thick/heavy to manipulate with a pair of pliers.

I got inspired by the Kit of No Parts:
http://web.media.mit.edu/~plusea/ And decided it was high time to make a 3D printable speaker prototype. I turned the basic design of a speaker upside down and put the coil on the bottom to simplify construction. (With magnets being as strong as they are lately this is probably fine.) You'll need a strong, light magnet (the little cube ones from makerbot are probably ideal) paper, and magnet wire. Once my ToM is constructed, I'll edit in my experimental results, patterns for paper, updates, etc.

Wrap the magnet wire around the inner "spool" shape a good number of times (probably 20 or more for best results, although I have no test data yet) and secure with glue or knots in the wire so it doesn't unwrap on you. Poke the wires out the bottom where they'll become your leads. Glue the magnet to the center of a paper circle (black construction paper will probably look quite legit) and glue to the speaker. Important: make sure the magnet is centered above the coil as well as possible.
Also important but less crucial probably: make tabs for the paper circle so that you're not gluing the whole rim, just the edges. This creates the "diaphragm" of the speaker. Plug into an amplifier, play sounds, hopefully.

Allows you to mount a Smoothieboard to your Rostock MAX's electronics bay door. The board is mounted with the electronics and LEDs facing outward, and is stood off from the door to accommodate all the connectors.  
The door hanger can be screwed into place, but it doesn't have to be. The two top standoffs on the mount are keyed to be force-fit into the door hanger. You will need four screws and matching nylon locknuts to fasten the board to the mount.  
The parts are thin and fragile in places. I've beefed them up by adding some strakes, which seems to help a lot, but they will break if you put too much force on them. Please be careful, and remember to wear an ESD (grounding) wrist strap. In particular, be cautious when plugging in or removing the USB cable. Hold onto the mount to stabilize it while you do this. Otherwise, you may shear off the top standoffs!  
Inspired by mhackney/EclecticAngler's mount.

I recommend printing with 3 loops, 33% infill on the mount, and 25-33% infill on the door hanger. Print with 50-100% infill if you want it stronger.  
Support is not necessary. Use layer cooling fans if you have them.

remixed_from.author: kresty
remixed_from.title: Individual STL and 2 Plate Total Ripoff of one of Emmett's Heart Gears placed to fit on my printer.

title: Arrow Through Gear Valentine's Heart With Stand!

description.text:
I couldn't stand just copying Emmett's heart, so I added Cupid's Arrow and a display stand.  
The arrow is in both dual-extrusion (because I can) and one-color versions.  The two tips and two tails WILL NOT work individually.  
If you want just a heart, look at the remixed from.  The stand will work with my version of the non-arrow heart as well.   
Allow 7-8 hours to print everything at .2mm layer height.   
Please support my projects

If you want to support my projects, check out and share my completely unrelated, yet still cool, Working Lego R2-D2 YouTube channel at http://www.youtube.com/MyL3G0 - I make a few pennies off the ads.
Arrow Through Gear Valentine's Heart With Stand!
I added a hole, arrow & stand to Emmett's heart. If you want a heart without the arrow/holes, check the "remixed from" on this thing's page: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:670944 Printing:

No rafts are needed. Support is only needed for the stand. Print the 2 plates and the center for the heart, I used red, 10% infill, .2mm layer height. Print the stand if you want it, I used gray, but whatever. 10% infill, .2mm layer height. Probably need to use supports when printing. Print the arrow, I used 0% infill, .2mm layer height, they have "built-in" supports that should snap off after printing.
  • Dual extruders can use the 4 STL, two for the tip & two for the tail. I made the fins/point red and the shaft gray.
  • Single extruders should print the one-color arrow, you can
    • Assembly:

Check out Emmett's heart for a video on tips to help assemble the heart: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:243278 Test each bit before snapping in, they'll be really smooth where they join. If not, something's messed up. A) The center has "small" faces and "big" faces. Start with a "small" face up, put a pin in each face.
B) Snap the V-notched middle of the top of the heart to the top small face.
C) One end of the middle part has a single tooth in the middle (the other side has two teeth around a space), line up that single tooth with one of the big faces, that tooth will be the "right" side of the heart.
D) Find the lobe, which has a hole for the arrow tail.
E) Attach the "lobe" next to that single tooth of the V gear. The hole is closer to the "top" of the lobe, and the top two center teeth should fit nicely over the single tooth of the V bit, we'll call this the right side of the heart.
F) The other gear with a hole has a mirror image, find both of those, they're fairly flat
G) The "hole" gear is on the front left, little teeth toward the lower right, big teeth toward the upper left. Find out where the teeth align nicely with the top V and snap in. It should feel pretty smooth if you got it right.
H) The mirror of the hole gear goes in the back of the V.
I) Find the oval/rounded gear, that goes on the left side, the bottom side should have a single centered tooth. This gear should fit smoothly between the two previous gears.
J) The bottom bit is next, it is the pointy gear. I think it's symetrical. The longer side aligns with the heart.
K) The last two gears are the smallest round gears. The smallest teeth go towards the center of the heart. If you can't make them fit, they're probably backwards. Add Arrow:

The arrow should slide into the holes and would form an imaginary straight line.  It doesn't really matter which end is which.  You may need a dab of glue to keep it snug  
Stand:

The stand is amost tricky.  Clean off the supports, then it fits between the gears in the back of the heart.  You may have to wiggle the gears a bit.  The stand blocks the gears, so you'll have to take it off the stand to play with it.  
Please support my projects

If you want to support my projects, check out and share my completely unrelated, yet still cool, Working Lego R2-D2 YouTube channel at http://www.youtube.com/MyL3G0 - I make a few pennies off the ads. remixed_from.author: Thirkell
remixed_from.title: Radial Spool Holder for Al Frame Prusa i3

title: Spool mount for Taulman spools, 7mm thick Prusa i3

description.text:
A bearing based spool holder for 1 Lbs rolls. Works well for 1Kg rolls too!
get a pair of 10cm, m8 threaded rods, eight 8mm nuts and four 608zz bearings. There are now two options for bearing guides, the second one is wider and will support other spools, particularly spools with thick flanges. Other than that, the length of your M8 threaded rods will determine spool compatibility. Designed to clear an extruder like this http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:99274
and not cover up the cool "Prusa i3" logo thing.
Also because the roll is right over the extruder, if the filament tangles a little while unrolling, it won't pull the x gantry so much, as compared to a DIY spool holder made of things already in the room near your printer.... update:
after using this for months I just had a failed print on a 1 lbs. roll of bridge nylon. I believe this is due to me dropping the roll and having it unravel a bit before starting the print. seems the filament formed a knot as it twisted off the roll, causing the cold end to chew through the nylon. I'm going to experiment with a system to prevent the roll from unraveling due to loss of tension during retract moves. update2: there's no easy/cheap way to prevent the roll from unraveling with this style of design. It would be much too complex. also it's not typically an issue: don't drop your rolls.

Get a pair of 10cm long m8 threaded rods,
8x 8mm nuts and
4x 608zz bearings. print 4 'elliptical bearing guide' and over extrude them a bit for strength (I decreased the filament diameter by 5% via slic3r, you could also change your default extrusion width to a little below your nozzle size... i was just lazy)
'elliptical bearing guide 2' is simply a wider version more suitable for many non-taulman spools 1Kg. print one 'left support' and one 'right support': I printed at 25% infill, .18mm layer height, they seem plenty strong. print 4 'spacer'. Assembly:
Get two nuts about a quarter of the way in on each 10cm rod, slide on a bearing per nut. slide the elliptical bearing guides over the outer races, they may need a dab of glue to stay put. Slide a spacer on for each bearing. Put the left and right supports on so that the smooth faces face each-other. Put the last 4 nuts on, adjust nut positions for the width of your filament spool and tighten. Mild thread lock may be useful, you don't want the roll to fall on your print!

description.text:
Instead of Using Makerslide, i decided to use the Openbuilds V-Slot. I basically modified to fit with the existing dimensions of the X-Gantry. The key modifications to this project are: -Using Openbuilds V-slot instead of Makerslide
-Using Solid V-wheels instead of V-slot Wheels
-Addition of J-head mount that works with the RP-one Labs J-groove Mount

Here is the BOM for now 3 x - M5 x 35 mm Screws
9 x #10 Spacers
3 x M5 Spacers
3 x M5 Nuts
3 x Solid V-wheel Kits The X-gantry will require 2x M5 T-slot Nuts instead of one.

title: EZStruder Trick Laser Arm Mount for Rostock MAX/Orion/etc.

description.text:
Are you using Trick Laser carbon fiber arms on your Rostock, Orion, or other 3D printer? If so, this will allow you to mount an EZStruder to one set of arms. (Or two, or all three!) The point of this is to reduce the length of the Bowden tube, thereby reducing the friction and hysteresis that can aggravate stringing and blobbing on Bowden machines. There is about a 50% reduction in Bowden tube length over mounting the EZStruder near the top of the printer! Get your Trick Laser arms here: http://www.tricklaser.com/Carbon-Fiber-Tube-Arms-with-Metal-Ball-Rod-Ends-for-Rostock-MAX-RM-ARM-CFTX.htm Changelog
2015-03-16: Replaced the EZStruder brackets with 15 and 25 degree versions of same (original tilts the EZStruder by 15 degrees). Also, replaced the hold-down with a version that will snap into place on the bracket and stay there, so you don't have to hold it during installation. Both 15 and 25 degree mounts have slightly deeper recesses for the hold-down, so you'll have to re-print if you're using and older version. 2015-02-20: Added a 30mm longer version of the slotted arm for people who are using a different arm setup. READ THE INSTRUCTIONS. There are things you need to know! In particular, this will limit your printable radius. You need to move the effector around after the mod is installed to verify how big you can print. I recognize this as a weakness in the mount. In the future, I plan to do a version that won't have this problem; it will be able to slide up and down on the arms, and perhaps pivot the extruder from side to side. Features
  • Shorter Bowden length (about 1/2 as long as stock!) discourages stringing and blobbing.
  • Uses heat shrink tubing to help absorb stepper vibration.
  • Makes the EZ-Struder whipser quiet! Retracts are almost totally silent, and skipping is much, much quieter than using the stock mount.
  • Slotted arm with flared mounting holes allows the arm to move freely, no matter what position the effector is in, without binding or constraining the Delta arms.
  • EZ-Struder is offset and angled to center the extruder's output with the hot end's input.
  • Mass of the extruder is close to the carriage hinge, so it doesn't have any leverage to sling the effector all over the place at high speeds (majority of momentum added is strictly up/down on the associated tower).
  • You can have three extruders (one per arm!) and still have room for another up top.

You will need the following extras:
  • 8 x 0.5" #6-32 machine screws, or metric equivalent
  • 2 x 1" #6-32 machine screws, or metric equivalent
  • 10 x #6-32 nylon locknuts, or metric equivalent
  • 2 x heat shrink tubing (wide enough to fit over the TL arms)
  • Scissors or something else to cut and slit the tubing
  • Screwdriver and wrench/pliers for the machine screws/locknuts
    • Optional:
  • Super Lube 51010 - http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000BXOGHY
  • Hairspray or water-soluble glue, like Elmer's "School Glue"
    • Filament Calibration
    The locking bolts need to fit properly into the nuts on the front arm plates. Print one Locking Bolt and one Locking nut test. The bolt and nut are keyed to fit together, so find the notch on the bolt and its matching groove on the nut. You should be able to fit the bolt into the nut, and with a little turn, get it to rotate 180 degrees. There will be a little resistance at first, but then it should turn freely. You should not be able to pull the bolt out again without first rotating it back to the position it was in when you inserted it. If you can, your filament flow is too low. If it's too hard to insert, or if you can't rotate it once it's inserted, your filament flow is too high. Printed Parts
    You need one of each of these:
    EZStruder Bracket
    Slotted Arm
    Locking Bolt Hold-Down
    Locking nut test You need two of each of these:
    Arm Plate Back
    Arm Plate Front
    Locking Bolt Once everything is printed, take the heat shrink tubing and cut it so that it matches the length of the arm channels (arches) in the front/back arm plates. Then, slit it lengthwise so you can fit it to the arms without having to dismount them from the printer. Now, it's time to install the arm plates. You want them towards the top of each arm, very close to the hinges but not necessarily all the way there. This is VITAL to the operation of the extruder! It has to be far enough away that the Bowden tube can bend as the effector moves around. You may want to use a little hairspray or water-soluble glue on the inside and outside of the heat shrink tubing to prevent it from walking down the arms over time. Holding the heat shrink tubing in place, put the front and back arm plates together on the arm with the front plate (the one with the protruding cylinder) facing towards the inside of the printer. Carefully tighten the screws and locknuts together, keeping in mind that the carbon fiber arms are hollow and brittle, and will break if you put too much pressure on them. You DON'T have to tighten the screws until the plates touch, and I wouldn't!!! You want the screws tight enough to hold the arm plates in place and not let them slide freely, but again, not too tight. You'll be installing the front and back plates to both arms, making sure that the cylinders on the front plates are pointing in the same direction. The arms will rotate right and left as the effector moves around, so it's important that the cylinders are level with each other. Take the slotted arm and mount it to the front arm plates such that the circular hole is over the left plate and the elongated hole is over the right plate. This is important because the slotted arm is offset to one side in order to center the EZStruder relative to the hot end. Install the locking bolts, rotating them 180 degrees. That done, use the 1" #6-32 screws and some matching locknuts to secure the EZStruder to its mount. The front of the EZ-Struder has mounting holes that should fit perfectly over the ones on the printed mount. Then, take the locking bolt hold-down, fit it to the channel in the "hook" part of the EZStruder mount with the top facing towards the extruder (see photo), and then carefully seat both parts on the slotted arm. The hold-down should fit right over the locking bolts, preventing them from popping out should anything go wrong. Cutting the Bowden Tube
    At this point, you should have an EZ-Struder pointing more or less straight at your hot end. Take a length of PTFE tubing and insert it into the EZ-Struder. Then, with the printer off, move the effector slowly as far away as you can from the carriage the EZStruder's arms are connected to. (More of the tube's length is needed the further the effector is from the extruder's carriage. The slow moving is necessary to prevent the steppers from generating back EMF and frying your controller.) Now that you have the effector as far from the extruder as it's going to get, move the Bowden tube into the position it would be in if it was seated in the hot end, add a few inches to be safe, and make a quick, hard, square cut with the sharpest cutters you have. The quicker and harder you cut, the less likely there is to be a deformation at the end of the tube. Fit the tube into your hot end. If there is any slack, and there should be if you did this right, trim it off using the same technique. SUPER IMPORTANT: Move the effector around with the extruder and Bowden tube installed to see how far you can move it from the center without stretching the tube too much. I find I can't quite go 100mm off center without stretching it too much. Make sure you don't ask the printer to print something that would cause the effector to travel outside this range! Don't skip this step - you may hurt your printer if you do!!! GOTCHAS:
    Make absolutely sure the Bowden tube won't get snagged on anything around the effector. I have a long screw protruding up from the hot end mount that I lash some wires to, and the tube got fouled up on that once. If the mount makes squeaking noises, a few drops of Super Lube (see above) will ensure months of quiet operation. The arm mounts may creep down slowly over time. You may have to move them back up once every few tens of hours. You can try lashing one of them to the carriage using some insulated stranded wire, or string. You can also try putting a little hairspray on the arms, and the insides of the arm plates.

comments.text: Some video?
comments.author: Renha

comments.text: Could you make a version of the slotted arm for 77mm spacing instead of 50mm spacing? Swapping over to Jfettig's effector design, think I can gain some z height and rigidity.
comments.author: nyl0cke

comments.text: The slot is actually a lot longer than it needs to be. Try it out and see if it'll work. If not, let me know and I'll whip something up the next time I'm in Sketchup.
comments.author: nyl0cke

comments.text: I saw the extra slop, but I don't think its quite enough to allow an extra 2.7cm distance. If you could that would be great.
comments.author: 626Pilot

comments.text: Alright, in a couple minutes a version stretched 30mm longer will be available.
comments.author: nyl0cke

comments.text: Thanks!
comments.author: 626Pilot

comments.text: Hey Pilot.  Do you find the extra weight on the arms to have any effect on printing?
comments.author: Tinyhead

comments.text: It doesn't seem to matter. I have a Z-probe which lets me test repeatability, and repeatability is the same with or without the motor mounted to the arms. Our steppers are not used at full capacity, so they have enough slack to handle the weight. The closeness to the carriage U-joints also significantly limits the parasitic inertia over what it would be if mounted on or near the effector.
comments.author: Tinyhead

comments.text: I would be worried about the weight on the carriage at a hard angle, like when the effector is maxed out at the opposite side of the plate from that tower.  I could see some skipping on the belts when it tries to move quickly.
comments.author: 626Pilot

comments.text: That is possible, I suppose, but most of my prints don't go all the way to the edge. Acceleration settings should be some help there, and there's a feature request on the KISSlicer forums for making Delta g-code slow down when one or more arms get close to horizontal.
comments.author: Tinyhead

comments.text: What material do you recommend these to be printed in? Yours look like PLA?
comments.author: nyl0cke

comments.text: I always print in PLA. I guess ABS would work fine too.
comments.author: nyl0cke

title: 3D printer Filament spool holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Spool holder to sit on top of a Mini Up printer, helps to feed Filament in straight and direct, excellent for 'wood' filament' and may be adapted for almost anything. Fits various spools with hole diameters of 57.5mm, 52.5mm, and 32mm.
Use 4 Skate bearings "608" size, bore 8 mm, outer diameter of 22 mm, width of 7 mm (press 2 into each Spool holder, gently press them in flush to the outer face and they will run true).
Axel, use 8mm Round bar.
Legs and braces, I used Aluminium tube, 12mm diameter for the legs and rear brace, 10mm diameter for the front guide (you could use dowel or anything straight). Optional Side brace fitting included for tall structures.

Funny how adding more RAM to my struggling iMac suddenly gave it a terrific performance boost to create better models in Photoscan. With that in mind, I revisited a recent project, a 19th century bronze model of the Statue of Liberty that was made to order by the Parisian foundry Thiebaut Freres. I'm thrilled with the improvement in detail, but I had to sacrifice much of the finest details to keep the mesh file small enough to meet the requirements for uploading and sharing it. The original model looks even better than this example. I still need to learn more about Meshmixer and Blender so I can better fix the many little flaws the 3D model still has. I'm looking forward to perfecting this! (I just recently was thrilled to see that it was printed with photos documenting how the model was slightly modified. You can see the link to the story here: https://re3d.org/a-beginners-guide-to-scaling-your-favorite-print/ Many thanks to Samantha Snabes for posting her story).

comments.text: Awesome! You will be a Mesh Master :-)

title: Another Spool holder with skateboard bearing for 3D printer 58mm internal diameter spool

description.text:
Yet another spool holder, this one is for a spool internal diameter of 58 mm which I couldnt find anywhere. Print 2 of these, push a skateboard bearing (22mm outer diameter) inside (its a tight fit- do it while it is still warm - straight off the hot bed.) Then you can mount your spool on a big nail hammered into a plank (or any other shaft mounting system!).
The spool spins really freely on the bearing. I printed mine with 30% fill and it was strong enough.
NOTE: You can stop the print when approx 5mm of the spool insert towers have been printed, no need to print the full length of spool inserts.

title: 40mm Fan Y Duct and Boot Dryer

description.text:
This thing is a solution to wet hiking boots the night before another hike...  
It is a Y duct that will fit over the opening to a set of hiking boots, blowing fresh air down into them to move moisture out.
I've also added some other fittings for use with cooling parts, or just making a Y-duct (short).
This prints very well on an UP!, but I've also printed these kinds of things on a reprap.  The Y duct has a bridge 8mm up, so use support.

description.text: Cookie love for Valentines?

This is a baseplate for building with Bitbeam. The width of this 20x20 Bitbeam plate is 160 mm by 160 mm. Holes are 5.0 mm in diameter. The center of each hole is 8 mm apart from each other. Bitbeam is an open source Lego Technic-compatible building toy. More info at http://bitbeam.org

To use this thing, you can either "Print now!", or "Configure, then print.": Option 1 (aka "Print now!"):
1) Download the attached STL file.
2) Using a slicing program to convert the STL into a G-code file for your printer.
3) Print! Option 2 (aka "Configure, then Print"):
1) Download the attached OpenSCAD file.
2) Modify the file to make a bigger or smaller baseplate.
3) Compile, render, then export as STL.
4) Go to Option 1. Please print one and post a photo! Warning: The STL file is very large. (7.8MB) Your slicing program may have problems converting to G-code if your computer doesn't have enough memory to process the file. If you don't have any problems slicing this STL, please add a comment with your OS, OS Version, amount of RAM, slicing program and version. (e.g. OS X 10.7.5, 4GB RAM, Slic3r 0.9.8.)

title: Da Vinci 2.0A Duo PLA fan holder 80cm

description.text: This is my 80cm fan cooler for PLA printing. Specially for difficult prints that have overhangs, without a fan I wasn't able to keep the curlings out. Prior this I used a fan on the side but the air didn't reach evenly. I used a 80cm fan, because that's what I got in hand. I had it usb connected directly to the printer, but I turned on after the 3-4 first layers, specially if they are the brim/rafts. Print it on ABS (because the heat too close to the nozzles) and to avoid hard-to-remove supports, print it on slic3r/simplify3d at 90 degress (stl it's already rotated), so you don't get any supports inside the air-exit. If you print it flat you might have problems removing the supports. Remember to keep the door open since it's the only area that it will hit. The clip and fan have a really nice grip, on fast prints it stays put, but if there's too much x-y shake, it might move, it shouldn't. Use it at your own risk. The design it's inspired from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:553792 by mordiev, but the measures and clip holder didn't did it for me so I have to start from the scratch. Note: Both parts do 'clip' ok, but if you are going to print with it, please glue both parts to avoid surprises.

title: Blackout Spider Hex Angled Gopro Mount

description.text:
A 15 degree angled mount for a Gopro on the blackout spider hex. Designed for fast forward flight. Lines up with the velcro strap holes provided on the vibration-dampening platform, but there's also holes if you want to screw it to the holes on the plate. I suggest using some thin double sided tape to keep it from sliding. I also suggest using a thin piece of shelf liner or moongel between the plate and the gopro.  
There is a file for a piece that mounts to the top, and a piece that mounts to the bottom— You can use them interchangeably, but using the bottom one on the top might make the plate stick out more at the front.  
Modeled in 3ds Max.

remixed_from.author: tedkeys
remixed_from.title: PrintrBase - ATX Power Supply Base for PrintrBot Simple Metal

description.text:
The Printrbot Development Platform, for desktop-friendly Printrbot tinkering!
  • 50mm fan mount to cool down foot and printrboard.
  • RaspberryPI B+ mount.
  • Arduino UNO + Breadboard mount.
  • Ultra LS 350W ATX housing.
    • All neatly forming a sturdy foundation that hides away all wiring and tinkering awesomeness that you would like to do.

Has been successfully printed on Simple Metal Printrbot's in different ways: Make One (draft made by myself):
  • 0.4 mm layer height
  • 1.75 mm ABS
  • 260C hotend
  • 90C heating bed
    • I printed the middle house with slot for fitting the ATX breakout board cable again with different settings, much faster with E3d vulcan hot end and Titan extruder. (See picture with red board attached to the side)
  • 0.6mm layer height
  • 0.8 mm hot end tip
  • 1.75 mm PLA+
  • 220C first layer, 205 rest
  • 70C heating bed
    • Make Two and Three:
  • 0.2 mm
  • 1.75 mm PLA
  • 200C hotend
  • No heating bed
    Ref - http://www.thingiverse.com/make:120451
    Ref - http://www.thingiverse.com/make:120693
    • You need to print out in all 6 modules:
  • 2 foot modules (front and back). This is the modules that the Printrbot will stand on. The front one has holes for attaching a 50mm fan and two power-switches with 6mm hole diameter as well as 4 led lights (for example to show if power-switches are on/off).
  • 2 housing modules for the ATX cabinet
  • 2 modules that forms a bridge between the 2 foot modules and the ATX housing
    • Note that there is a version 2.x of one of the foot modules that supports attaching an ATX Breakout board with its acrylic housing. This is useful if you would like an all in one powerbench using bananaplugs as well. You will no longer need the jumper cable on the ATX if getting an ATX breakout board. See this post for more info: http://dangerousprototypes.com/2013/02/18/atx-breakout-board-v1-2/ Once all is printed (it takes 6-16 hours per module depending on the quality you choose you can assemble them. Start with the ATX housing, that's easiest.

  • The ATX goes standing up with the fan facing right, power cable and button facing back and all the other cables facing front. Put in plastic strips in the holes first, make sure the knot goes on the outside as it is very tight. Screw the bottom piece first, then the top. If the holes are misaligned, you can drill new ones (will fix this eventually)

  • Attach the bottommost strips with the bottom bridge module (the non-triangular one). Wait with the triangular one to last as it gets tricky otherwise.

  • Attach the back foot (the one with Arduino + Breadboard mounts in it). Make sure that you face the side where the rails ends in a wall backwards towards the bridge module. Strip it together with the bridge module.

  • Strip together the front foot (the one with fan facing front, RaspberryPi B+ mount and rails going through the whole top).

  • If you printed the back foot that has screw holes for the ATX breakout board, now is the time to fasten it to one of the sides (you choose!). You can attach the cable also to it.

  • Cables you don't need can be bundled together within the bridge modules (and covered with the triangular top piece)

  • Cables you need you can stretch through the two feet (in the middle). You can always strip them to the sides using the two circular holes in the middle foot.
    • Separate instructions will follow for powering the RaspberryPi B+, Arduino and other devices once I got it going. If you don't plan to do this you can always lead your power cables through the triangular back holes and on the sides of each foot. At last, place the Printrbot on top of the rails gently. It should be very snug and sit tight. It is easiest if you lower it straight down as the rails are quite deep. Have fun! :)

title: TBS Gemini Perfect Hover Stand
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Ok one thing that can be a little tricky is getting the Gemini in a perfect orientation to set level. This is due to no flat surfaces, except for the small area under the motors on the CF "legs". I have just completed my design of the 3D printed Gemini leveling stand. It consists of a base with two circular posts which insert tightly into the holes underneath the center two motors in the CF frame. These posts press in until the frame rests against the larger diameter of the stand. When flush the printed base will provide an easier way to ensure the Gemini is in the proper orientation for setting level. In front of the base is an arm with protruding stand-off with a recess for a standard 1/4-20 nut and large head machine screw. This screw can be threaded up or down, pressing against the bottom case (towards the front of the Gemini) until the motor shafts are perfectly vertical. If the 3D printed base is placed on a perfectly level surface, and the machine screw adjusted until the motor shafts are vertical, you can be assured of a perfect hovering position in which to calibrate level. Important I scaled up this model in X and Y by a factor of 1.019 (No change in scale in Z however) to allow for ABS shrinkage on my printer. You may need to alter this scale somewhat for your chosen printer and material type to get it precisely correct dimensionally. Update 2-17-15: I have added a new version! Rev B includes a smaller outer base for faster printing, a groove on each side to provide a visual cue for vertical as an alignment aid for the motor shafts, and slightly smaller diameter inserts for engaging the base of the Gemini easier.

I used 20% infill and 2 shells. No supports are required. Please note that the file has been scaled up in the x and y axes by a factor of 1.019 to allow for shrinkage on my printer when using ABS. Your printer may behave differently, especially if you use a different material than ABS.

An oloid is a 3D object formed by the hull of a two linked congruent circles placed in perpendicular planes, so that the center of each circle lies on the other circle. With those two circles, if you generate the inner ruled surface, you get a nice knot...
Based upon "the Wallace Line" blog (http://kitwallace.tumblr.com/post/85762927079/ruled-mobius-strip) here is an adapted openscad script allowing to easily print the two halves of the oloid knot see http://youtu.be/EWawYvZxRKE

printed in black PLA, no support
  • layer 0,2mm
  • nozzle 0.5 mm
  • add a 6mm brim
    • Print 2 halves, trim them with a knife, glue them, sand the edges If you want to compile the openscad file, you need openscad version 2014.12.30 or above ... EDIT 8/02/15 : I realize I hadn't posted my latest .stl file, fixed now !

Nothing to see here. You really want version 3: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8252 (although this is still a good reference for the benefits of the accessible aspects. Version 2 now uploaded. Generate STLs from the version 2 scad to get the version 2 changes. NOTE: To do this you must have configuration.scad from the prusa git repo in the same directory as gregs-wade-v2.scad so that bolt and nut sizes defined in that file can be used. This is an extruder based strongly on the wades from the Prusa git repo. It has several features over the standard wade:

  • Accessible hobbing. If you strip the filament, there is no need to disassemble in any way (such as removing the idler/filament or bolt) in order to remove the stripped plastic from the hobbing. You can get a needle in the hole in the top and scrape it out.

  • The motor can be removed without removing the large gear. The three mounting screws can be accessed without removing the gear. 2 of them are clearly accessible and the other is accessible through a hole in the gear.

  • Slightly higher gear ratio than standard wade. This design uses 43:10 instead of 37:11.

  • The rotated motor mount means that the carriage attachment screw is accessible with the motor installed.

  • The rotated motor mount also means that the clearance past the idler attachment captive nuts is a bit longer, so you have a bit more play tensioning the idler.

  • The motor is far enough back from the face that the small gear can be mounted with the hub towards the motor (necessary with short shafted motors) and it will mesh with the large gear when there is only 1 washer between the bearing and the large gear.

  • The large gear has a shallow nut trap so that locking halfnuts can be used with hobbed threaded rod (infinitely adjustable hob alignment) rather than a bolt.

  • The motor mount screws are recessed allowing the large gear to be almost against the face of the extruder body.

  • It has sexy curves.
    • Things I still plan to do:
    Add some options to the way the small gear mounts on the shaft. I have always had problems getting that right (hence http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5213). Version 2 Changes:
  • Added the 4th idler screw hole.
  • Moved the top captive nuts for the idler screws closer to the idler so that you can screw the idler bolts in further
  • Made the motor mount slots go a further 1mm away from the hobbed bolt (as requested by spacexula)
  • Added the framework for hotend mount supports (I still need people to tell me what their particular hotend mounting needs are). Each hotend defines its holes assuming that the extruder block is sitting vertical with the filament exit hole at [0,0,0]).

Individual STLs are provided as well as print plates to print the idler and body in one go with standard settings and both gears in one go with fine settings. The STLs are for version 1. Generate new STLs from the scad to get the new changes Depending on your hotend, you may need to add hotend-specific mounting holes. The mount has been designed for a hotend I am working on with my father.

comments.text: Printed upside down so that the teeth are printed at the same time as the teeth on the big gear and they have time to cool. If the small gear was printed on its own you would probably have problems with tooth definition because the layers had not cooled sufficiently to be rigid when the next layer was being applied.

title: ZMR 250 Spacer Kit , Tilted Motor Mounts

description.text:
More Information on my original thread on RC Groups, : http://www.rcgroups.com/forums/showthread.php?t=2256768 Frame Spacer Kit :
  • 7mm Spacer (4)
  • 10.3 mm Clearance between lower & upper Frame
  • Requires M3 20mm Bolts, I only use 2 per Arm, strong enough.
    • LED Holder :
  • 10.3mm LED Holder (2)
  • Use any LED strip with a maximum of 10mm height
  • Mounting either with double-sided Tape or Hotglue / CA from Hobbyking
  • There is also a simplified version available, without overhangs, and the groove has been removed, for easy printing.
    • I use the Turnigy High Density R/C LED Flexible Strip from Hobbyking, they are 8mm in height 10° Tilted Motor Mounts :
  • They are labeled with F (Front) and R (Rear).
  • Calibrate your Naze while LEVEL, then add 10° Pitch Offset via CLI : align_board_pitch = -10
  • 1806 and 2204 Motors Supported.
  • Because of the Angle, you might have to slightly enlarge the holes on the arms.

Here is a model of a computer that I am sure many of you had growing up.  This is the infamous Amiga 1000 computer, a machine that was years ahead of its time.  Now you can be the ultimate nerd and have a 3d printed version of one of the best computers ever made in history!  3dsmax model.

It's easy, set the infill you want, and the mm height.  Use supports and you're set.  Nearly a day later and you'll have this awesome model.  The one I printed and displayed here was done in gold PLA by rainbot3d.  I think I did 10% infill on this one, and it took 9.3 hours!  Enjoy and please share pics if you print one.

Awesome Bumper for Nexus 4 mobile phone. I hate to use a bumper to increase the size and thickness of a mobile phone while designers are trying to get their phone small and thin. However with glass on both sides Nexus 4 looks really fragile. So I designed this.

Print on any machine you like.
I Print it on Replicator2 with 0.15 mm layer height and 20% infill. Higher infill is recommended to avoid failure when you try to use it.
when finished, you need to "slide" you nexus 4 in.
You can even change the STEP and IGS file to modify the design and make it fit your own cellphone! The easiest one would be a Galaxy Nexus. :)
BTW: I've marked this model with a Dorabot Logo, which is my open source robot project. If you don't like it, just download STEP or IGS file and change it for you own Logo.

remixed_from.title: 5.8GHz FPV 12 Turn Helical Antenna (5645 Frequency) RcHobbysUK Beam Width 31.3 Degrees

description.text:
Wire turning template is shortened from original made by xack and mirrored both right- and left-hand version. Pillars ver.1 has smaller holes for smaller ~1mm wire.
And ver.2 is for thicker ~1,5mm wire. Added 3-turn versio for ~1mm wire [easy to drill bigger hole].
Added -fix -versio of pillars that has little increased diameter to fit and maintain rounded wire diameter better. 5-turn, -3dB beam width is ~48deg. At 10m far, beam is 8m width.
3-turn, -3dB beam width is ~62deg. At 10m far, beam is 10m width.

Glue pillars together.
Pillars works both right- and left-polarity, just note right polarity in assembly point by rotating one half by 180 deg. Pillars can be screwed to reflector with ~2,5mm screw. Reflector min. diameter 32mm. Could be bigger, no harm. Shape don't matter also, square/rounded how you want.

This rack consists of a custom number of 4mm and 8mm slots.  The spacing between the slots is 8mm.  The holes are automatically placed on the outside edges but if the number of slots is small they will be placed vertically instead of horizontally.  In the STL I posted I used 8 slots of each size.  
Update (18-April-2015): I modified the script a little to reduce the height of the backplate and added a couple of variables to make it easier to tweak.  I also updated it to work with customizer.

I printed this with the fingers on the bed.  There is a lot of surface area if you print this with a large number of slots.  I did 16 in my picture and I did get some curling on the edges.  I had the bed heat off and did not put any glue down before I started though.

description.text: I had some spare ecig mod parts laying around and had the idea to make a mod powered by the 12v accessory in my car. This is a simple design and really cheap to make.

Parts needed:
LM2956 step down converter
10k ohm knob style potentiomer
12v car accessory plug
12mm momentary push button
voltage readout display
510 ecig connector The LM2596 comes with a small potentiometer built onto the board, but to make it easy to adjust voltage you need to swap it out for the knob style pot. I also put Kapton tape between the pot and the lm2956 so it wouldnt short out. The 12v accessory plug has a 5amp fuse. Other than that the build process is pretty self explanatory. Let me know if you guys have any questions. :)

description.text:
Similar to the thing it derives from, except this time it mounts onto a servo horn.  Typically a round one of roughly 20mm in diameter.  
This thing allows you to mount an 'arm' onto a servo using an embedded circular servo horn.  It has a total of 12 mounting holes, to match those on the servo horn, although you're likely only to use 4 of them.
Material was removed from the middle in an effort to reduce the potential for warping, and to make the print time shorter.  It should still have the same strength and rigidity for the typical uses of this thing.
Also, instead of accomodating a 608 ball bearing, this one accepts a simple bushing on the end.  This is a simpler and cheaper linkage joint.

1) Print as many of these as you need
2) Mate each one to a servo horn by placing the horn inside the larger receptacle, and screwing into the horn from the outside. The opening of the horn that mates to the server should be facing outwards.
3) Slip the assembly onto the servo axle
4) Fasten to the servo axle using the tiny screw that comes with the servo horn
5) Rejoice! The lighter weight should require just that much less torque from the servo, which is a good thing.

Many of you probably had this Apple computer back in the day before I anything when google wasn't trying to eliminate the desktop computer, and machines didn't use the same programming languages.  I was a child during these times and my father picked up a Commodore 64, I only used these Apple 2's at school.  At that time in about 1983, Apple and Commodore were donating computers to school for education.  Made in 3dsmax

Print as oriented in the file to get the best .mm resolution.  Use supports.  Several hours later you'll have an awesome model that many of your friends might just say "This took how long to print?  What does it do?"  But you'll love it anyhow.

author: smfirer

description.text:
A custom made clutch pedal extension for Logitech Driving Force GT.
Fits next to the original pedal set. I plan to screw those together. In addition to the printed parts you will need
  • a long enough 6 mm bolt or a piece for 6 mm threaded rod
  • couple of 6 mm nuts and spacers
  • 4 x 3mm screw to connect the pedal to the pedal arm
  • possibly some screws to mount everything on a platform
  • electronics to drive the thing
    • For electronics I used a PIC18F2550 microcontroller on a stripboard to read input from a limit switch connected to the pedal assembly and to provide USB connectivity. Photos and a Lochmaster 4 files are included to show the stripboard design. Board is installed inside the pedal. Included source code for PIC18F2550 requires CCS C compiler to build.

comments.text: Brilliant idea! I will try and build it

comments.text:
Yes, that's how my PIC implementation works.
The pedal acts as a USB keyboard and sends a keycode when pressed.

comments.text:
I am not an expert with electronics either. I used a PIC18F2550 microcontroller. Pictures of the board and source code is included in the files.
It might be easier to do it with an Arduino or a Raspberry Pi - at least that wouldn't require any special hardware to flash the chip.

comments.text:
I used a PIC18F2550 on a piece of stripboard to read clutch input and to connect to a PC with USB.
I assume the bolt was a 6mm or a piece of 6mm threaded rod.
I updated the Thing with some more details.
